overview: From 2026-01-18 to 2026-01-25, elizaos-plugins/registry had 2 new PRs (0 merged), 0 new issues, and 10 active contributors.

topPRs.title: Add Cerebras Plugin
topPRs.author: Xayaan
topPRs.body:
**Cerebras AI Plugin** Fast LLM inference plugin using Cerebras AI's industry-leading inference API. No local GPU required. Includes support for: - Advanced reasoning capabilities (GLM, Qwen, GPT-OSS models) - Strict JSON schema validation for structured outputs - All latest Cerebras models including zai-glm-4.7 Key Features - Direct Cerebras API integration via OpenAI-compatible format - Reasoning support with configurable depth (low/medium/high) - Structured outputs with strict JSON schema validation - Multiple models: Llama 3.3, Qwen 3, GLM 4.7, GPT-OSS 120B - No GPU required - cloud inference at 2000+ tokens/sec Why This Plugin? Enables blazing-fast LLM inference without expensive GPU infrastructure. Cerebras delivers the fastest inference speeds in the industry, making your ElizaOS agents more responsive and cost-effective. # Registry Update Checklist Registry: - [Y] I've made the left side of the colon of JSON entry in index.json match the potential NPM package name - [Y] I've used github not github.com - [Y] There is no .git extension - [Y] It's placed it alphabetically in the list - [Y] I've dealt with commas properly so the list is still valid JSON If not an eliza-plugins official repo, i.e. new plugin: The plugin repo has: - [Y] is publically accessible (not a private repo) - [Y] uses main as it's default branch - [Y] I have include `elizaos-plugins` in the topics in the GitHub repo settings. If the plugin is related to `AI` or `crypto`, please add those as topics as well. - [Y] add simple description in github repo - [Y] follows this convention ``` plugin-name/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images/ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ logo.jpg # Plugin branding logo ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ banner.jpg # Plugin banner image ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts # Main plugin entry point ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions/ # Plugin-specific actions ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ clients/ # Client implementations ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ adapters/ # Adapter implementations ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ types.ts # Type definitions ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ environment.ts # runtime.getSetting, zod validation ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json # Plugin dependencies ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md # Plugin documentation ``` - [ ] an `images/banner.jpg` and `images/logo.jpg` and they - Use clear, high-resolution images - Keep file sizes optimized (< 500KB for logos, < 1MB for banners) - Follow the [elizaOS Brand Guidelines](https://github.com/elizaOS/brandkit) - Include alt text for accessibility - [ ] package.json has a agentConfig like the following ```json { "name": "@myNpmOrg/plugin-example", "version": "1.0.0", "agentConfig": { "pluginType": "elizaos:plugin:1.0.0", "pluginParameters": { "API_KEY": { "type": "string", "description": "API key for the service" } } } } ```

Greptile Summary

- Adds new Cerebras AI plugin (`@elizaos/plugin-cerebras`) to the registry for fast LLM inference capabilities without local GPU requirements - Maps the plugin to `github:Xayaan/plugin-cerebras` in the correct alphabetical position in `index.json`

Important Files Changed

| Filename | Overview | |----------|----------| | index.json | Added `@elizaos/plugin-cerebras` entry mapping to external repository; requires verification of plugin repository structure |

Confidence score: 4/5

- This PR is safe to merge with minimal risk but requires verification of external repository compliance - Score reflects proper JSON formatting and registry conventions but deducted one point due to missing plugin branding assets noted in the checklist - Pay close attention to the external repository at `github:Xayaan/plugin-cerebras` to verify it meets all ElizaOS plugin standards

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant GitHub participant Registry participant Scripts participant NPM User->>GitHub: "Create PR with updated index.json" GitHub->>GitHub: "Run automated validation checks" User->>GitHub: "Merge PR" GitHub->>Scripts: "Trigger generate-registry workflow" Scripts->>Registry: "Read index.json" Scripts->>GitHub: "Query repo info for @elizaos/plugin-cerebras" Scripts->>NPM: "Query package metadata" Scripts->>Scripts: "Process compatibility checks" Scripts->>Registry: "Update generated-registry.json" Registry->>Registry: "Commit updated registry files" ``` ## Summary by CodeRabbit * **New Features** * Added Cerebras plugin support, expanding available integrations for the platform. ‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.

topPRs.title: Add @elizaos/plugin-sportradar to registry
topPRs.author: project-aeris-disaster-agent
topPRs.body:
## Plugin: @elizaos/plugin-sportradar ### Description Sportradar NBA API integration for ElizaOS - enabling AI agents with live sports data capabilities including live scores, schedules, rosters, player stats, standings, and injury reports. ### Features - üèÄ Live Game Updates - Real-time scores, play-by-play, and game statistics - üìÖ Schedule Access - Season, daily, and team-specific schedules - üë• Team Rosters - Current rosters with player status and details - ‚≠ê Player Stats - Individual player profiles and career statistics - üìä Standings - Conference and division standings with win/loss records - üè• Injury Reports - Team and league-wide injury reports - üìã Boxscores - Detailed game statistics and scoring breakdowns - üîç Natural Language - Understands team nicknames and player references ### Repository https://github.com/elizaos-plugins/plugin-sportradar ### Actions Provided The plugin provides 12 actions: 1. GET_NBA_TEAMS - Lists all 30 NBA teams 2. GET_NBA_SCHEDULE - Season schedule for specified year/type 3. GET_NBA_DAILY_SCHEDULE - Games for a specific date 4. GET_NBA_LIVE_GAME - Live scores and game updates 5. GET_NBA_TEAM_ROSTER - Team roster with player details 6. GET_NBA_PLAYER_INFO - Player profile and statistics 7. GET_NBA_STANDINGS - Conference standings 8. GET_NBA_PLAY_BY_PLAY - Detailed play-by-play data 9. GET_NBA_TEAM_STATS - Team statistics and records 10. GET_NBA_BOXSCORE - Detailed boxscore for games 11. GET_NBA_TEAM_SCHEDULE - Team-specific schedules 12. GET_NBA_INJURIES - Injury reports ### Configuration Example ```json { "name": "MyAgent", "plugins": ["@elizaos/plugin-sportradar"], "settings": { "secrets": { "SPORTRADAR_API_KEY": "your_api_key_here" } } } ``` ### Integration Testing - ‚úÖ Plugin follows elizaOS plugin architecture - ‚úÖ All actions properly implemented with handlers - ‚úÖ Error handling for API failures - ‚úÖ TypeScript types exported - ‚úÖ Natural language team name resolution - ‚úÖ Provider for NBA context injection ### Changes - Only modified `index.json` as required - Added entry in alphabetical order between `plugin-spheron` and `plugin-sql` - Format: `"@elizaos/plugin-sportradar": "github:elizaos-plugins/plugin-sportradar"` ### Documentation Full documentation available at: https://github.com/elizaos-plugins/plugin-sportradar ## Summary by CodeRabbit * **New Features** * The Sportradar plugin is now available for public use and integration within the platform. Users can access sports data and analytics capabilities through this new plugin. The addition expands the available integration ecosystem, offering enhanced functionality for users seeking sports-related data services and analytics features. ‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.

Greptile Summary

This PR adds the Sportradar NBA API plugin to the elizaOS registry following proper contribution guidelines. ## Changes Made - Added single entry `"@elizaos/plugin-sportradar": "github:elizaos-plugins/plugin-sportradar"` to `index.json` - Entry placed in correct alphabetical order between `plugin-spheron` and `plugin-sql` - Format follows registry requirements: NPM package name mapped to GitHub repository reference - No other files modified (as required by contribution guidelines) ## Plugin Details The plugin provides NBA sports data integration including: - Live game scores and updates - Team schedules and rosters - Player statistics and profiles - Standings and injury reports - 12 total actions for comprehensive sports data access ## Registry Processing Once merged, the GitHub Action will automatically: 1. Process the plugin entry via `generate-registry.js` 2. Query GitHub API for repository metadata 3. Fetch package.json to determine version compatibility 4. Check `@elizaos/core` dependency ranges for v0.x and v1.x support 5. Update `generated-registry.json` with complete plugin metadata

Confidence Score: 5/5

- This PR is safe to merge with no risk - The change is minimal and follows all registry contribution requirements: only modifies `index.json`, adds a single entry in correct alphabetical position, uses proper format (`@npm-package`: `github:org/repo`), and points to the official elizaos-plugins organization repository. The automated registry generation process will handle validation and metadata extraction after merge. - No files require special attention

Important Files Changed

| Filename | Overview | |----------|----------| | index.json | Added `@elizaos/plugin-sportradar` entry in correct alphabetical order between `plugin-spheron` and `plugin-sql` with proper GitHub reference format |

Sequence Diagram

```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant PR as Pull Request participant Index as index.json participant GHA as GitHub Action participant Script as generate-registry.js participant GH as GitHub API participant NPM as NPM Registry participant Output as generated-registry.json PR->>Index: Add @elizaos/plugin-sportradar entry Note over Index: New entry added alphabetically
between plugin-spheron and plugin-sql Index->>GHA: Trigger on push to main GHA->>Script: Execute generate-registry.js Script->>Index: Read plugin entries Script->>GH: Fetch repository metadata GH-->>Script: Return repo info (description, topics, stars) Script->>GH: Get branches (main, 0.x, 1.x) GH-->>Script: Return branch list Script->>GH: Fetch package.json from branches GH-->>Script: Return package.json with version info Script->>GH: Get git tags for versions GH-->>Script: Return v0 and v1 tags Script->>NPM: Query package metadata NPM-->>Script: Return published versions Script->>Script: Analyze version compatibility
Check @elizaos/core dependencies Script->>Output: Write generated-registry.json Note over Output: Includes full metadata:
versions, branches, compatibility,
description, topics GHA->>Index: Commit updated generated-registry.json ```

topContributors.summary: madjin: Focused on stabilizing the documentation site's data pipeline by identifying and resolving critical issues related to missing API files and null contributor summaries (#225, #226, #228). They successfully merged a fix to ensure stats are correctly re-exported after summary generation (#229) and addressed edge cases where no-activity days caused generation failures. Their work primarily centered on bug fixes and configuration improvements to ensure the reliability of the site's automated reporting and API indexing.

0xbbjoker: Focused on maintaining ecosystem stability and version alignment, notably resolving TypeScript compatibility errors for @elizaos/core 1.7.x in the Telegram plugin via PR #24. They also managed the release preparation for the Discord plugin, executing a version bump that involved significant code and configuration updates across 27 files in PR #44. Their work this week primarily centered on bug fixes and configuration management to ensure seamless integration across core plugin repositories.

odilitime: Focused on a massive architectural overhaul of the elizaos/eliza core, specifically working on the V2.0.0 dynamic execution engine as seen in PR #6384. This high-impact effort involved substantial code modifications across over 1,800 files, totaling more than 100,000 lines of changes to test context-driven execution logic. Their work this week was primarily dedicated to large-scale bugfixes and feature development aimed at stabilizing the next major version of the engine.

standujar: Focused exclusively on large-scale bugfix work this week, executing substantial code modifications across 239 files with over 11,000 lines of total churn. They also played a significant role in quality assurance by providing 6 detailed pull request reviews, including three critical change requests and seven technical comments. Their primary impact centered on stabilizing the codebase through extensive file-level corrections and rigorous peer feedback.

matomoniwano: Focused on architectural expansion by developing a prototype for the RLM provider within the Eliza Python core, as seen in the ongoing work for PR #6383. This effort involved substantial modifications across 16 files (+610/-223 lines), prioritizing the foundational infrastructure required for this new integration. Their primary focus this week centered on configuration, documentation, and testing to ensure a robust framework for the prototype.

greptile-apps: Focused exclusively on collaborative quality assurance this week, contributing five reviews and one pull request comment across the codebase. While no code was merged or issues opened, their activity centered on providing feedback and technical oversight through the review process. Their primary impact was driven by peer review and maintaining development standards rather than direct code contributions.

shuhaib112: Focused on collaborative quality assurance by providing two reviews on open pull requests. This engagement indicates a focus on maintaining code standards and supporting peer contributions through technical feedback. Their primary activity this week centered on the review process rather than direct code implementation.

ChristopherTrimboli: Focused on a mix of general maintenance and bugfix work this week, contributing eight commits that modified 50 files with a balanced volume of code changes (+489/-574 lines). They also supported the team's development flow by providing a pull request approval, ensuring continued progress on peer contributions. Their primary efforts were centered on system stability and addressing technical debt through various file updates.

borisudovicic: Focused on product refinement and feature definition for the elizaos/eliza ecosystem, driving the implementation of an agent discovery module (#6302) and establishing a standardized public agent link format (#6304). They also actively managed the platform's stability and user experience by identifying dashboard bugs (#6382) and proposing interface simplifications in the app builder (#6385). Their primary impact this week centered on project management and triaging issues related to the landing page and dashboard functionality.

lalalune: Executed a massive codebase cleanup and restructuring, contributing a single high-impact commit that modified 776 files with over 74,000 total lines of changes. While they did not merge any pull requests, they remained engaged in the development process by providing three targeted comments on ongoing pull requests. Their primary focus this week was centered on large-scale repository maintenance and file-level refactoring.
